Fields.DialogueText: Lampo, what's with all the smoke?
I was trying to make some pasta, but the results were unpleasant.
I can see that. Kind of surprising - I'd have thought that it would be your specialty.
Well, it is my heritage, but I just haven't really focused on learning about it. I know how to make machine parts fit together just right, but mixing in sauce is something else.
So what got you in the mood to try your hand at cooking?
... I feel ashamed that I can't make food worthy of my homeland.

Fields.MenuText: You're getting better with every try. Just hang in there.
Want me to help you?
You should be proud of the things you're already good at. You don't need to prove anything.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you. Pola will be amazed when I'm through with this batch.
Are you sure? Well, thank you. It's nice having help; two heads are better than one.
I know, but... I want them to be proud of me.
While you're here, could you get another fire extinguisher, please? This smoke keeps getting worse.
Yeah, we need to stop the fire before the whole ship starts cooking.
*ALARM*
See? What did I tell you?
It appears that our campfire attracted a Morgana.
Don't worry, Capitano, she'll regret messing with me.
I know she will. You're always two steps ahead of them.
@BATTLE
I'm already proud of you, Lampo. You're the best friend and dreamer anyone could have.
Thank you, Capitano.
Looks like we're in a tough spot now.
With Morganas around us on all sides, closing in? Most certainly.
I guess this was how the Roman gladiators felt just before the wild beasts were let loose.
At least they didn't have to worry about drowning when they fell.
Actually, sometimes they did. Nero among others sometimes liked to flood the Coliseum for special events.
Wow. Ingenuity must run through your blood, doesn't it?
Yes, that sort of visionary drive is one of our most fundamental traditions, the core of our pride. And with them, we will bring a glorious new age to the world.

Fields.MenuText: Then let's use that cleverness to get out of this mess.
You have a lot of great ideas, Lampo. I'm sure they'll catch on.
In that case, they should value your ideas more.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't worry. This lady has some crafty tricks up her sleeve.
Thanks. I just have to keep trying.
... There's a lot at stake. Failure is not an option.
All right, Capitano, I found a weakness in their formation.
Great! Time to break up their little game.
@BATTLE
Morganas closing in! Prepare for battle!
@BATTLE
Great job out there, Lampo. You really showed those Morganas who not to mess with.
Thanks, Capitano.
You're welcome. Now we can finally rest a bit.
Actually, Capitano, I wanted to ask you...
What is it?
Since we finished the battle, I was wondering if I could please go speeding around for a bit?
Now?
Yeah. After an intense fight like this, I like to get a bit of fresh air and exercise.

Fields.MenuText: What about repairs?
Sure. Just don't run anyone over.
We still need to keep an eye out for more enemies.

Fields.DialogueText: I can fix things on the fly, no problem.
Don't worry. The first thing a racer learns is how to avoid crashing.
If they get close to me, they'll be the ones to regret it.
Knock yourself out - metaphorically, I mean.
Hang onto the rail; I'm taking off!
Whoa! I guess all that energy has to go somewhere when we're not in a battle.
Um, Lampo?
Yes? What is it, Capitano?
Well, I was going to ask you about the marbles lying around - I almost tripped down the stairs! But first, what exactly are you building along these halls?
I am trying to make a full marble "castle" that stretches across the whole ship.
It is kind of neat, I admit. I didn't know that you liked playing with marbles so much.
Well, there's another reason to my interest.
Ah, so it's connected to one of your special projects?
An early idea I had for a futuristic city. The design got scrapped after I submitted it to headquarters, but I decided to take another look at it from a different perspective.

Fields.MenuText: So what are the marbles supposed to represent?
The structure of your city is kind of fragile - I accidentally broke part of it when I was coming in, sorry.
What gave you the idea for the city?

Fields.DialogueText: They are the city's transit system - you get in and then ride along to different destinations.
I know, but that's okay. Part of why I built it like this is so I can figure out how to fix the weaknesses.
One day when I saw a ball rolling down the stairs. Then ideas just started rolling in my head.
I have to say, that would be an interesting city. So what's the next step?
Testing out the sphere transport system. Want to be the lucky tester?
I'll... think about it.
Suit yourself. I'll just pick things up and...
Of all the times for a Morgana to send a wave crashing into us. But no point worrying about spilling our marbles - we have a job to do.
@BATTLE
Sounds like you'd get really dizzy.
Just goes to show that you can find inspiration everywhere.
Let's see... how to do this? La de da de da... !
Whistling while you write?
Rather I'm whistling so I can write.
Oh, I see. You're trying to compose a musical score.
Yes. I wanted to expand my artistic expertise, and this was something that interested me.
How's the music composition coming along?
Pretty well - I just need to think up a good finale for the piece. Then I need to decide on lyrics - or no lyrics.

Fields.MenuText: I'd love to hear you play it when it's ready.
Well, I can see how this would work well for you; music composition requires a lot of calculations, I've heard, and you're really smart.
What sort of theme are you going with for the song?

Fields.DialogueText: Of course! Maybe we could try to play it together.
Thanks. Artists and scientists have something else in common: a drive to discover new things. Even if the challenges are trying, I still push through.
Something that embodies the pastoral beauty of the Italian countryside, yet also the mystery of the sea.
Well, I'll just let you get back to your work with the music.
Actually, that will have to wait. I just detected a Morgana nearby.
Nuts. Sorry, Lampo, you'll have to set that aside for now.
The frenzy of battle can be its own inspiration as well.
@BATTLE
That will be a wonder for the ears.
Trying your hand at another painting?
Yes, but it is harder than it sounds.
I know, it's tough getting your ideas to work on the canvas...
No, I mean that I'm nervous that my canvas is going to fall into the sea at a moment's notice. One sudden shake and off it goes over the side.
I see. That is a problem.
Unfortunately, I don't know what I can do except just hope it works out.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe you could invent something to help you?
Can't you do the painting further away from the deck?
If it does, it's not the end of the world. You can always start over from scratch.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, but that requires time I don't currently have.
I could, but I want to capture the water's vivid nature up close. The trouble is getting close enough.
You're right. Just have to live and learn. Even if there are setbacks, I can start over.
Well, you're almost finished...
Wah, my painting! No!
It's okay - I caught it in time.
Thank heavens. That was quite a rough wave we hit right then.
Rough is definitely the proper word for it. The monsters that birthed the wave are even rougher.
@BATTLE
Lampo, Lampo!
Sorry, Capitano, I couldn't hear you with these headphones - what is all that racket?
The merry sounds of a Morgana symphony.
Oh, merda. I'm sorry, Capitano, I didn't mean to get so involved in my work.
It's okay, just pay closer attention. But now that you know, could you get up on deck? We need your support!
I'm sorry, but I was in the middle of some delicate procedures. I need to finish them properly before I can leave them be.

Fields.MenuText: We don't have the time.
Then make sure you do a good job with it. I trust that whatever you have cooked up will come in handy.
Don't worry. You're speedy on the battlefield, so that will make up for any delays.

Fields.DialogueText: Okay, I get it! I am a woman of many tasks.
It's going to improve my repair speed, ironically enough.
Thanks. I may get outpaced when I'm distracted, but I catch back up as soon as I'm focused!
Everything's good to go down here, Capitano! So hang on!
Whoa! You can at least put your tools away where they won't go flying!
No time for that, Capitano! We have a fight to win!
@BATTLE
Lampo, what's going on down here? It looks like you're renovating the whole ship from the inside out!
Capitano, watch where you step, or... !
Wait, wah! Why is there a big pool of water down here? Don't tell me we have a leak!
Don't worry, I was just making a small bath.
This is a lot bigger than a bathtub.
Well, that is because I'm making a Roman bath. Think of it more like a spa.
Are you certain this is... feasible on a ship?
It will be, when I am finished here. In any case, this pool at the very least is ready for operations. Want to take a dive?

Fields.MenuText: What made you think that a full bath house would be a good idea?
Is the plumbing going to be able to handle all of this?
You did a really good job with the design.

Fields.DialogueText: I thought it would be a great way for everyone to relax after a long day. The Romans did it; see how far it got them?
No problem. Roman architecture, enhanced by my own know-how, is nigh foolproof. It will be safer than a titanic dam.
Thank you. I worked really hard to get everything right.
Okay, just a little dip.
Well, how is it?
It's actually pretty nice. Sometimes you just want to sit back, let the waves roll by...
*ALARM*
That is the one little issue - the acoustics here are amplified.
If you can still hear me, get on deck.
@BATTLE
Funny how you mention the Titanic...
*SPLASH*
Nice painting you have there. You have remarkable talent as an artist.
Thanks. Actually, though, this is something else.
Oh, I see. This is for the city idea you've been working on, right?
Correct. Technical blueprints have their own value, but sometimes it's good to visualize things.
It looks really nice. There's an empty spot right in the center, though.
I'm... still uncertain what I should put there. It will symbolize the very heart of the city, so it needs to be perfect.

Fields.MenuText: Follow your heart, and just paint whatever comes to mind first.
You should have a good idea of the theme from the rest of the city, so you just need to apply the ideas you instilled in the rest of the picture.
It's alright to leave it for another day. Sometimes inspiration comes and goes like the wind.

Fields.DialogueText: Good idea. True art is built on passion. I just hope this works...
That's right. I just need to find a way to combine the individual themes around the city...
Maybe that's for the best. I could use a break.
I think I've got it. A little-- what the?!
That's an interesting stroke there.
That's because my hand slipped. I spotted a Morgana fleet.
Well, we'd better take care of it.
Yes, indeed. There won't be a world for my city unless we stop them.
@BATTLE
Let's see, how would the jetpacks work?
Working some more on your Aetherial Babylon city?
Yes. Right now, I am trying to figure out how the propulsion systems would work. They need to function on a continual basis; one slip and everything would fall down.
Well, I'm sure you'll come up with something. Does it really need to fly, though? At this stage, at least. I mean, it would be cool, but it's not really necessary.
Maybe... but at least they won't have to worry about the sky.
What do you mean?
Perhaps it is simply paranoia, but I have always had this unsettling premonition about the sky.
A premonition?
It's the one area that I cannot fully defend myself against. I can fight anything at sea, but planes and the like can fly over me unharmed. Somehow, I think that will be my undoing.
So you want to overcome that weakness through flight.
Exactly! It's just tougher than I first imagined.

Fields.MenuText: Everything in life has its own dangers. You just have to learn to live with them.
We never know what the future has in store. So no use trying to worry too much about hypotheticals, right? If anything happens, we'll face it together.
That's all good, but don't get so preoccupied with your fears that you forget about the positive things, like the joy of flying. That's another good motivation.

Fields.DialogueText: I know, but I have a drive to improve things. Together, we can move forward to a better, safer future.
Thanks for being there with me. I'm still afraid, but at least I know that you're here to help.
You're right. It wasn't just the fear of the sky that engaged me in the idea - it was the yearning to drift closer to the stars.
Well, at least the Morganas don't know how to fly. That would be a real nightmare.
Good point. Even so, they're pretty aggravating.
Tell me about it.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Lampo, why are you examining the railings with such a perplexed look on your face?
Oh, no reason. Why do you ask?
It's just, the last time you had that look, it was right before you decided to make that bath.
And it worked out great, right?
Yeah, but that doesn't make me any less worried now.
I just thought that these support frames are a little insecure for my taste. So perhaps we could gradually switch to pillars?
Pillars?
Yes. They are quite reliable, and the marble would look very nice in the light.
Wait, marble?
Of course. Anything else would look cheap.

Fields.MenuText: We don't have the resources for that right now, Lampo.
It's up to you. Just remember that I already like you the way you are.
That would be interesting.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right. We need to focus on winning the war. Still, maybe after things settle down.
You really think so? The current supports do have a sentimental value, I admit.
Yes, certainly. However, there are other projects that I might want to work on first.
Maybe I should leave the pillar refurbishing for another time.
Good. We don't really have the freedom of time for major constructions. You never know when a Morgana might show up to do some wrecking of its own.
Well, I know when: now.
@BATTLE
Lampo, what's wrong? You're crying!
It's ruined...
Oh, I see, this contraption you have got smashed. Was it some sort of toy you invented?
No, not a toy, but that's all Pola thinks it's worth. And maybe she's right...
What do you mean?
This was supposed to be a model for my dream city of tomorrow. But I showed it to Pola and...
She broke it?
On accident. She was just playing around carelessly, without taking my model seriously.

Fields.MenuText: How about I help you fix it up?
It's okay, just let it all out.
Your dreams are not foolish.

Fields.DialogueText: Really? It will be a lot of work...
*Sob...* Thank you, Capitano. Now that I've let out my tears, I can concentrate and move forward.
Yes... my ideas have value, I know it. And they will be fulfilled in the end. They'll all see!
Well, if it's any comfort, your city looks amazing, even in its current state.
Thanks. I just wish I could get my mind off it for a little while.
Looks like your wish came true.
@BATTLE
Hey, what are friends for?
Lampo, are the guns ready yet?
Um, Capitano, we have a small problem.
I think having a Morgana fleet approaching is more than a small problem.
Not that - the baths sprung a leak.
Great. Now what?
Don't worry, I can fix it up in a jiffy. I just need a little more time.

Fields.MenuText: Just make sure you hurry. There's not a moment to lose.
Make sure you do a careful job down there. We don't have much time, but haste makes waste.
Focus on limiting the leakage, and then get back to the battle. We can do more work once we survive this one.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll do my best.
You have a keen mind, Capitano. You're absolutely right - if we don't do a good job with the repairs, we might make things even worse.
Good idea. Best to prioritize our problems and deal with what we can.
I fixed the leaks, though we still have a lot of water down in the hull.
We can bail it out later. Right now, we need to sink the Morganas before they sink us.
@BATTLE
Nice of you to join me for another swim, Capitano.
No problem. You really did a great job with the pools.
Thanks! After that last incident, I put extra attention into making everything perfect. Now the Marco Polo Baths are ready for action!
Marco Polo? I didn't think that he was a Roman.
Well, no, but he is still a famous adventurer from Italy, so it was only right that I named it after him.
You must admire him a lot.
I do. He was such an amazing hero - a scholar, a sailor, and an artist all rolled into one.

Fields.MenuText: Some of his stories may have been embellished.
I thought he traveled by land, not sea.
Those are some pretty large shoes to fill on your own.

Fields.DialogueText: I for one believe that they were all true.
You're wrong. He did some sailing during his return trip to Europe.
I know, and sometimes I get scared. But if he could face so many unknown dangers, who am I to hesitate? I will make him and my home proud.
Well, you certainly chose a fine name for the baths.
I know, right? I just hope that I can discover wonders like those he witnessed. Maybe even create some.
Well, we're making history right now, holding the Morganas at bay.
You're right. Now it's time to carve another chapter in our story. Those Morganas are going down!
@BATTLE
Are you sure? I mean, the story mentions people with dog heads!
And yet you are talking to a ship with a Belle.
Hey, Lampo. What's up?
Nothing much, just recalibrating some of the pressure gauges. Lots of *pressure* to get things done right, ha.
You are really good at this sort of work.
Thanks! I like fixing things up.
Do you think you could teach me?
Teach you? Why?
Well, you seem to enjoy it a lot. So why not?
Okay. Just take a seat and pass me the wrench - no, the bigger wrench. Watch and learn.

Fields.MenuText: Wouldn't I learn more if I directly participated?
Maybe I can teach you something in return later.
Thanks. I'm learning a lot.

Fields.DialogueText: You can still learn a lot of stuff just by watching. Galileo just watched weights fall off towers, and he figured out critical insights nevertheless.
Do you think you could teach me to cook Italian food - or Chinese, or something?
You're welcome. It's good to know that my skills are appreciated.
Well, that's that! Did you pay attention?
Yes. I learned a lot.
We all have our own strengths. For one, you know how to get us out of tight spots - like now!
@BATTLE
Sure. It's the least I can do.
Say, Lampo? Something has been bothering me about your whole city idea.
What about it? Please, say what you wish - I strive to make the finest city of the future, one that will bring new hope to Italy and the world.
That's actually what I am wondering about - exactly what country will your city belong to?
I beg your pardon?
Well, I've gotten the impression that you are making the city for Italy, but you also talk about having it travel the world.
I... don't know.
I'm sorry, I didn't mean to trouble you like that.
It's okay. It's just... I don't know who I want the city to belong to. Or who will claim ownership once everything is said and done.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe it will be a nation of its own, a free spirit on the sea.
I suppose you want to first offer it to Italy.
You're going to have to decide eventually, one way or another.

Fields.DialogueText: Like us out here. That is the sort of wild determination that inspired the idea for me...
I do. But... I don't know if they will accept it or not. And I'm not sure which would be worse.
I know. I just wish there was a way to make everyone happy.
Well, you don't have to worry about it right now. We have a long way to go with it - and the war.
Yeah, let's leave that for another time. But still, I wonder...
What?
... Why those Morganas always keep showing up at moments like these.
@BATTLE
Capitano! I just spotted a Morgana on the horizon!
Great! Man the guns and... wait, what is it doing?
You're right; it seems to be going away from us.
Why? This isn't their usual behavior.
Perhaps they have finally learned to fear us?
No, they're bloodthirsty and stubborn to the last. They always hunt their target to the ends of the earth.
But what if we aren't the target this time?
You're right! We can't let it get away.
We won't. What are your orders, Capitano?

Fields.MenuText: Shoot it down from a distance.
Catch up with it as fast as you can.
Contact the rest of the fleet. We'll need backup to corner it.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll try, but we need to get closer first.
No sweat! Full steam ahead! Charge!
You're right; they'll want some of the action, too. But first we need to make sure it doesn't leave the party early.
I'm almost to it, Capitano.
Good. Brace yourselves; we can't let it get away this time.
@BATTLE
Come on, Tazio! You can still win this one!
Having fun listening to the races on the radio?
Yes. It's the Grand Prix of Brescia - one of the finest races across Italy.
How's your champ doing?
He's hanging in there - he'll win the race for sure!
You must really love the sport.
It's a national pastime, and our pride. The greatest roads of yore always led to Rome, you know.
Well, I'll leave you to the races - don't mind me.
Actually, this reminds me...
Don't tell me you want to try the ship deck race track idea again!
However did you guess? But, not exactly. What I want to do is design a ship specifically meant for races at sea.
That's a new approach.
I figure that, since it's so hard refitting the ship so that it can accommodate a track, best to just have it installed from the beginning. What do you say?

Fields.MenuText: That sounds really interesting.
What sort of Belle do you think that ship would be like?
You'll also need to design cars that can function optimally at sea.

Fields.DialogueText: Thanks. I think it would be awesome.
I don't know, actually. A race car lover like me, for one.
Good point. You have to take every little thing into consideration for big projects like this.
You certainly have an imagination, Lampo.
Thank you, Capitano. I'm just sorry that so few of my ideas apply to our current straits.
That's okay - they give us things to dream of, and encourage us to end this war.
You're right. Let's show these Morganas the bright light of the future!
@BATTLE
Merda! Why, why?
Lampo, what's wrong?
I got some new orders from headquarters.
What did they say?
I am to cease my work on "frivolous" projects and focus my engineering skills solely on war machines.
What?!
They said that if I'm not helping the war directly, my spare time should be spent on something productive.
But this means a lot to you!
I know, but what can I do?
Well... who says you need their approval?
What do you mean?
We're out here on our own. You can still go through with your dream, with or without your nation's direct backing.
I don't know...

Fields.MenuText: You have a lot of friends willing to help you with your ideas - me, for one.
If your government does not see the value of your work, let them live with the loss. They'll change their mind when they see what you can do.
It's ultimately what you want to do with your life, Lampo. No one can tell you what to do with your life.

Fields.DialogueText: Thanks. This means a lot to me. How can I ever repay you?
... I guess you're right. They'll change their mind in the end.
I... want to create new wonders for the world, ones that will help encourage a new age of imagination. And I will not surrender that dream, no matter what.
Are you sure that you want to help me with this, Capitano? It will be tough doing it on our own, and we have a lot to deal with.
I'll help you make your dream possible, Lampo. Nothing, not even those accursed Morganas, will keep us from moving forward with it.
@BATTLE
You already have, by giving us new hope for the future.
All right, the first order of business for managing your special project is the funding. How has the recent issue changed things?
Well, I didn't get much before, but I still got a small stipend for design projects.
So we need to find a way to make up for that loss now.
More than that - the stipend wasn't a lot, but it was enough for the planning phases. Once we get to the serious testing, though, I was counting on more support.
Well, maybe we can all chip in a little.
I don't want to just live off of charity, though. I thought that the government appreciated my ideas, and that was why they put money into my projects.
In that case, maybe one of your other talents could earn some cash to support your side work.
Like what?

Fields.MenuText: You could do a singing performance - some traditional Italian operetta, perhaps.
You could sell some of your art pieces - they're really amazing.
We could host a special race and charge admission.

Fields.DialogueText: That might be nice. I'm just a little nervous about doing it in front of everyone.
I don't know; it takes time for art to gain value. But it would be great to share my pictures with others.
Really? Are you sure? I thought that you never wanted another race track on the ship.
Well, now that we have an idea on how to procure resources, we can proceed with planning the city. ... Or not, now that a Morgana has showed up.
I am sorry about keeping you busy with this.
Not at all. All in a day's work.
@BATTLE
You'll sweep them off their feet.
Well, maybe only once more.
Hello there, Capitano. I was just looking for you - I have my latest sketch for the city.
Oh? Let me see... It looks fantastic.
Thank you.
Though, there is one thing I notice; the design is missing weapons.
I told you, this is for a more peaceful era. It does not need weapons.

Fields.MenuText: Okay, I won't press you about it.
Even if the war ends, that does not necessarily mean that everything will be peaceful.
Having a few defense systems implemented might make the project more feasible right now.

Fields.DialogueText: Thanks. But, with what they've said to me, I wonder if I'm just a hopeless dreamer.
Things will improve, you'll see. It has to get better, right?
Maybe... I just feel like I am selling out for immediate demands.
I'm sorry I brought that up, Lampo. It's not that important, really.
I know, but you're right. Maybe I should just set the project aside.
Lampo, it is your bright optimism that gives such life to your ideas. Don't give up just yet.
Thanks.
Besides, even if your designs are all peaceful, you are not a peaceful lady on the battlefield.
Not at all! Those Morganas will regret backing me into a corner.
@BATTLE
Hey, Capitano? I want to ask you something.
What's that, Lampo?
I'm still trying to figure out the specific design for my city, and I wanted to get your thoughts on it.
What do you need me to do?
Well, I have a lot of ideas for the city, but I need something to give it a sense of distinct culture. So I have to ask... what would be your favorite city?

Fields.MenuText: Atlantis.
What would be your favorite city?
My hometown.

Fields.DialogueText: But you have never been to Atlantis.
That is a tough question. I have a number of favorite cities throughout Italy - and China has some wonders as well.
You're right - we all have attachments to our homes. So how do I make something that can be everyone's home?
Sorry if I wasn't that helpful.
Oh, no, you gave me a lot of food for thought.  Any questions you have for me?
Just one: how long do you think it will take us to deal with those Morganas?
Not too long, once I get into the thick of it.
@BATTLE
Nobody has. That's what makes it so intriguing.
An interesting perspective.
How's the project coming along, Lampo?
I'm getting there. I just need to find a way to reach the hearts of everyone across the world, so that everyone finds inspiration in the new city.
Maybe you should ask them, then?
What do you mean?
Well, I thought that maybe you should share your idea with a wider audience - a global audience. Then you could get everyone's opinion on the city.
I don't know... What if they say it's silly again?

Fields.MenuText: You can't please everyone, Lampo. But if you look long and hard enough, you'll find a lot of people who like your thoughts.
You have to believe in yourself, Lampo. If you want your dream to become real, you need the guts to unveil it to the world.
Maybe you could start out by talking with the other Belles. They come from a variety of origins, so they would offer a diverse set of perspectives.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll think about that, Capitano.
Well, that's all I can ask, I guess. But don't worry, you'll figure things out. You just need the right inspiration.
Yes, one day it will be complete!
It would probably would be easier if these Morganas weren't around to divert our attention.
@BATTLE
What was that?
Oh, Capitano! What brings you out here?
I just wanted to chat - at least, until I saw one of our lifeboats whiz by in the air and then explode.
Sorry, that was an unintentional side effect. I'll do better next time?
Next time?! Is this some new attempt at boat racing?
No, I was testing out my theory on how to make a flying ship.
Why the lifeboat?
I wanted to do some tests before I install them on myself. You always seem to get nervous about those kinds of things, so I wanted it to be perfect.
I wonder why...

Fields.MenuText: You need to let me know before you do experiments like this.
We need the lifeboats for emergencies.
Try to make sure the final ones don't explode.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm sorry. I'll let you know in the future.
I forgive you. In any case, it was kind of cool, I admit. If I had known, I could have watched the whole launch.
I made a replacement lifeboat to make up for the one I used. But I understand.
Good. The Titanic was a technological marvel, but it would have been even better if they remembered the safety features, too.
Don't worry, I'll keep finding new improvements.
That's the spirit.
Well, back to the old drawing board.
Hey, you've gotten a long way from the start, so just keep at it.
I will. Oh, will you look at that. I think our little flare attracted company.
@BATTLE
Capitano, Capitano! Great news!
Can this wait until we're out of this mess?
No, it can't! I... think I've finished the design for Aetherial Babylon.
You have? Great! Is that the final name?
I need a good name for the city. Might you have a suggestion?
Me?
Yes. It was because of you that I persisted. So I want you to have the honor of naming it.
Tough honor...

Fields.MenuText: Actually, Aetherial Babylon sounds pretty cool.
Figlia di Lampo? Since you said it's your baby in a way.

Fields.DialogueText: Really? I'm glad you like it.
I... heh.
Anyway, I am really happy for you.
Thank you. I couldn't have gotten there without your help.
Hey, we're all in this adventure together.
All right, then. Let's get back to business and finish these sea monsters off! They have nothing compared to our teamwork.
Actually, Aetherial Babylon sounds pretty cool.
